questions.question: Principles, policies & framework, (b) Processes, (c) Organization structure, (d) Roles, responsibilities & risks of IT department, (e) Culture, ethics & behaviour and (f) Services, infrastructure & applications are six of the seven enablers of COBIT 5. Which is the 7th enabler?

options.text: Information
Planning & communication
Delegation of authority
Compliance with statutory regulations

questions.explanation: Information is the 7th enabler under COBIT 5. Hence, answer at Option A is the correct one.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Principles, policies and framework in an organization ?

options.text: To control the employees
To arrive at the business strategy of the organization
To convey the management s direction & instruction
To comply with statutory regulations

questions.explanation: The purpose of Principles, policies and framework in an organization is to communicate downward the direction the management would like the organization to take and the means through which this can be done. They reflect the culture, ethics and values of the organization. The objective is not to control the employees; not are they in compliance with statutory regulations. Principles, policies and framework are not drawn up for the purpose of business strategy; however, the strategy will evolve based upon these elements and other strategic inputs like the market, competition, etc. Hence, answer at Option C is the correct one.

questions.question: Apart from being effective and efficient, what other characteristic should a good policy possess ?

options.text: To control the employees
Making sense & appearing logical to those who have to comply with them
To arrive at the business strategy of the organization
To comply with statutory regulations

questions.explanation: The third important attribute of any good policy is that it makes sense and appears logical to those who are required to comply with them. But for this, policies would fail in actual practice during implementation for want of buy in. Hence, answer at Option B is the correct one.

questions.question: Processes are one of the 7 enablers of Governance of Enterprise IT under COBIT 5. What are the types of processes distinguished under COBIT 5 ?

Group processes versus individual processes
Governance processes and management processes
Macro versus micro processes

questions.question: How does the RACI (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed) model help in an organization ?

Basis for development of organization chart
Accelerates decision-making process

questions.question: In Governance of Enterprise IT, the IT Strategy Committee should include _____________

Non-Board members alone, considering the need for implementation support

Board members and IT managers alone

questions.question: Which of the following has primary responsibility for implementation of Governance of Enterprise IT ?

options.text: The Managing Director or CEO of the Organization
The CIO of the organization
The IT Strategy Committee
The IT Steering Committee

questions.question: Which of the 7 enablers of COBIT 5 is considered the most important ?

Principles, policies & framework
Processes
Information

questions.explanation: Information is considered the most important of the enablers of COBIT 5. Answer at Option D is the correct one.

questions.question: What is most important in developing a performance management system ?

Identifying enterprise goals & their linkage to operating environment
Developing clear organization structure
Benchmarking with industry

But for this, the entire exercise would be fruitless since the performance could be directed at goals other than those established through the vision / mission of the organization. Answer at Option B is the correct one.

questions.question: A good performance management system assesses performance against goals through Answer: Goal Indicators. Simultaneously, it monitors performance of process through _________

options.text: Work flow indicators
Moving average indicators
Process Indicators
Industry benchmarks

questions.explanation: Monitoring of performance of process is through the Process Indicator. Hence, the answer at Option C is the correct one.

questions.question: The approach of using lead indicators for performance measurement is called __________

options.text: Reactive approach
Retroactive approach
Proactive approach
Retrospective approach

questions.explanation: The approach of using lead indicators for performance measurement is called Proactive approach. Hence, the answer at Option C is the correct one.

questions.question: The approach of using lag indicators for performance measurement is called ?

options.text: Proactive approach
Reactive approach
Retroactive approach
Retrospective approach

questions.explanation: The approach of using lag indicators for performance measurement is called Reactive approach. Hence, the answer at Option B is the correct one.

questions.question: Where is the Capability Maturity framework of Performance Management Systems generally used?

options.text: Hardware Development Company
Research & Development institution
Software Development Company
Educational institutions

questions.explanation: The Capability Maturity framework of Performance Management Systems is generally used in the software development companies. . Hence, the answer at Option C is the correct one.

questions.question: Mr Johnson has just taken charge as Head of a fledgling educational institution which has not had a good track record. He feels that he has his task cut out for him he needs to focus more on the lead parameters rather than lag indicators so that he can create sustainable results. Which of the following would be an example of lead indicators ?

options.text: Number of passes by students in the Matriculation examination
Number of all-India rank holders from the school in the Matriculation examination
Number of failures in the Matriculation examination
Number of hours of refresher courses attended by teachers

questions.explanation: The correct answer would obviously be the number of hours of refresher courses. Hence, the answer at Option D is the correct one.

questions.question: In Governance, value creation happens through Benefits Realisation, Risk optimization & Resource Optimization decisions taking into account _________

options.text: All Stakeholders needs
All Shareholders needs
Organizational goals
Organizational vision, mission

questions.explanation: In Governance, all stakeholders needs should be taken into account while taking decisions related to benefits realization, risk optimization & resource Optimization. Hence, the answer at Option A is the correct one.

questions.question: Which framework specifically enables users to relate their enterprise s current business & IT environment to specific objectives & relevant processes ?

options.text: Quality management system
Six Sigma approach
COBIT 5 framework
Blue Ocean framework

questions.explanation: While many frameworks may address such linkages generically, the advantage of COBIT 5 is that it specifically enables users to relate their enterprise s current business and IT environment to specific objectives and relevant processes. Hence, the answer at Option C is the correct one.

questions.question: The Balanced Score Card is an invaluable management tool that helps translate strategy into action and also for ________________

options.text: Balancing share holders needs with employee needs
Bringing non-financial indicators into better focus
Balancing needs of multiple functions within an organization
Balancing lead and lag indicators

questions.explanation: As brought out in Option B above, one of the major advantages of the Balanced score card mechanism is its ability to focus on non-financial indicators too, thus bringing in a balance between financial & non-financial parameters. The answers in other Options are incorrect.

questions.question: The Balanced Score Card is designed to ensure that performance metrics and strategic themes are balanced with financial & non-financial, operational & financial, lead & lag indicators. Financial, Customer & Internal Business process perspectives are three of the four perspectives of BS

options.text: Learning & Growth
Shareholders versus Employees
Short term versus Long term
Lead and lag indicators

questions.explanation: As brought out in Option A above, the fourth perspective of BSC is Learning & Growth. The answers in Options B to D are incorrect.

questions.question: The Balanced Score Card ____________

options.text: Is meant for the use of only the senior level executives
Cannot be linked to the IT goals & objectives
Cannot be the basis for performance incentives
Can be cascaded down to all levels of the organization

questions.explanation: As brought out in Option D above, the BSC can, indeed, be cascaded down to all the levels of organization. The answers in other options are incorrect. Justification The CIMA Strategic Score Card approach addresses both conformance as well as performance, focussing on strategic issues. The answers in other options are incorrect.

questions.question: Strategic position, Strategic options and Strategic implementation are three of the four basic elements of the CIMA Strategic Score card. What is the fourth element ?

options.text: Strategic Risks
Strategic Conformance
Strategic Performance
Strategic IT

questions.explanation: The fourth element of the CIMA Strategic Score Card approach is Strategic Risks. The answers in Options B to D are incorrect.

questions.question: What is fundamental to the Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI) ?

options.text: Used universally, except in the I.T. industry
Is superior to COBIT 5 which does not have process capability
It is a process improvement approach
Focuses on internal process alone

questions.explanation: The CMMI model is a process improvement approach & is a preferred model for the IT industry. COBIT 5, too, has process capability built in. CMMI addresses all processes. Hence, answer at Option C above alone is correct. Justification TQM strategy aims at achieving long term success through customer satisfaction. It aims to do this through quality management at all levels, improving products, services, processes as also culture. Hence, answer at Option D above alone is correct.

questions.question: State True or False. The guidelines for specific processes and procedures in COBIT 5 have been designed robustly with the latest best practices incorporated. While implementing the framework, these processes / procedures need to be kept intact and not tweaked or tinkered with.

options.text: FALSE
TRUE

questions.explanation: The design of processes and procedures suggested in COBIT 5 need to be tailored appropriately to suit the needs of the enterprise s culture, management style & IT environment. The recommended best practices, too, should be adapted to suit the particular enterprise where it is being implemented. Hence, the statement in the Stem is incorrect and the answer at Option A is correct.

questions.question: One of the primary reasons for implementing Governance of Enterprise IT (GEIT) is to alleviate pain points in the organization. Another major reason is ______________

options.text: Ensure up-to-date technology
Trigger events like merger/acquisition, new regulations, etc.
Achieve stake holder satisfaction
Higher vulnerability of IT compared to other functions

questions.explanation: The other major reasons for implementing GEIT are trigger events which create changes in the environment. Answers in Options A and C may also be factually true but are not necessarily major reasons for implementing GEIT. Answer in Option D is not correct. Hence, the answer at Option B is correct.

questions.question: Which one of the following could be a Critical Success factor in GEIT implementation ?

options.text: The project is handled exclusively & in isolation to day-to-day business
Execution authority & responsibility is retained at the highest levels
Top management provides direction and mandate
Trigger events like merger/acquisition, new regulations, etc.

questions.explanation: One of the critical success factors above is the need for top management to provide direction and mandate for the project, as indicated in Option C. Integration of the project with day-to-business is essential for the success of the project contrary to what is stated in Option B. Similarly, authority & responsibility have to be cascaded down to the level at which project implementation happens, ideally at the level of an anchor person. Trigger events may precipitate the implementation of GEIT but cannot be critical success factors. Hence, the answer at Option C is correct

questions.question: Which one of the following could be a Critical Success factor in GEIT implementation ?

options.text: Trigger events like merger/acquisition, new regulations, etc.
The project is handled exclusively & in isolation to day-to-day business
Focus on quick wins to demonstrate benefit & build confidence
Execution authority & responsibility is retained at the highest levels

questions.explanation: Early successes help instil confidence in the initiative & stimulate co-operation, as indicated in Option C. Trigger events may precipitate the implementation of GEIT but cannot be critical success factors. Integration of the project with day-to-business is essential for the success of the project contrary to what is stated in Option A. Similarly, authority & responsibility have to be cascaded down to the level at which project implementation happens, ideally at the level of an anchor person. Hence, the answer at Option C is correct.

questions.question: What should be the first phase of GEIT implementation ?

options.text: Forming an implementation team
Communication desired vision
Enable operation & use
Establish desire to change, stressing pain points, trigger events

questions.explanation: The first phase of GEIT implementation is preparing the ground for the project to take off and targeting the mind sets of the people concerned. This can be done by identifying the pain points / trigger events as also the consequences of inaction for the organization as well as the individual. The answers in other options can be successive steps in the project implementation and not the initial one. Hence, the answer at Option D is correct.

questions.question: What should be the final phase of GEIT implementation ?

options.text: Establish desire to change, stressing pain points, trigger events
Communication desired vision
Sustain changes through conscious reinforcement
Enable operation & use

questions.explanation: Any initiative, however good it may be, will not yield the desired results unless mechanisms are built in for sustaining the momentum which has been gained in the initial launch. This can be done, as pointed out in Option C above, through conscious reinforcement & continuous top management commitment. The answers in the other options are intermediate phases in the GEIT implementation process and, hence, are not correct.

questions.question: In line with ISO/IEC 38500, Governance processes under COBIT 5 are based upon the principles of ______________

options.text: Evaluate, Direct, Monitor
Align, Plan & Organize
Monitor, Evaluate & Assess
Build, Acquire and Implement

questions.explanation: Governance process under COBIT 5 are based upon the principles of Evaluation of strategic options, Direction to IT & Monitoring of the outcome. Hence, answer in Option A above is correct and the other answers are wrong.

questions.question: The most critical factor in implementing GEIT is ______________

options.text: Taking a bottom-up perspective
Identifying implementation scope & objectives, prioritization of processes
Availability of trained individuals to spearhead the project
Organization chart combined with Delegation of Authority

questions.explanation: The most critical factor in implementing GEIT is identifying implementation scope and objectives as also prioritization of processes, as shown in Option B. Answers in other options are not correct. Hence, answer in Option B above is correct.

questions.question: How is alignment of strategic IT Plans with business done?

options.text: Holding regular meetings with IT department participation
Having an IT department nominee in non-IT meetings
Clearly communicating the objectives & accountabilities
Taking a bottom-up perspective

questions.explanation: Alignment of strategic IT Plans with business is done by clearly communicating the objectives & accountabilities so that they are understood by all & IT strategic options are integrated with the business plans as required. Hence, Option C is the correct answer.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a management practice for aligning IT strategy with enterprise strategy ?

options.text: Identify gaps between current & target environments
Taking a bottom-up perspective
Holding regular meetings with IT department participation
Having an IT department nominee in non-IT meetings

questions.explanation: Identifying gaps between the current & target environments is one of the management practices for aligning IT strategy with enterprise strategy. Hence, Option A is the correct answer.

questions.question: How is Value Optimization of IT achieved ?

options.text: Going in for low cost IT equipment
Replacing full time IT employees with outsourced personnel
Taking a bottom-up perspective
Value Optimization of business processes, IT services & assets

questions.explanation: Value Optimization of IT is achieved through value optimization of business processes, IT services & IT assets. Hence, Option D is the correct answer.

questions.question: Which of the following metrics could be used for evaluation of value optimization ?

options.text: Number of low cost IT equipment procured during a financial year
Replacing full time IT employees with outsourced personnel
Percentage of IT enabled investments where claimed benefits were met or exceeded
Wage cost reduction through non-filling of some vacant IT positions

questions.explanation: One metric which could be used for evaluation of value optimization could be the percentage of IT enabled investments where claimed benefits were met or exceeded. Answers in other options, however, will not meet the requirement. Hence, Option C is the correct answer.

questions.question: COBIT 5 has a resource governance process to ensure that resources needs of the enterprise are met in an optimal manner. Which one of the following is governance process to be followed ?

options.text: Evaluate, Direct and Monitor resource management
Build, Acquire and Implement
Align, Plan & Organize
Monitor, Evaluate & Assess

questions.explanation: The governance process to be followed in this case is Evaluate, Direct and Monitor resource management as brought out in Option A. The answers in the other options B to D are incorrect and not applicable to the instant case.

questions.question: Which one of the following is an important tool used for managing & monitoring service providers ?

options.text: Regular meetings
Third party inspection arrangements
Service Level Agreements (SLAs)
Cost comparison through industry benchmarking

questions.explanation: While all the answers in the options above may be true to some extent or the other, the most important tool used for managing & monitoring service providers are Service Level Agreements which play the role not only of enforceability of commitments but, simultaneously, of capturing clearly the responsibilities of both parties as also other aspects like delivery expectations, escalation clauses, penalties, etc. Hence, the answer in Option C above is correct and the rest can be deemed to be wrong.

questions.question: The success of capacity management would depend most upon which one of the following factors ?

options.text: Historical trend of capacity expansions
Availability of precise and timely business forecasts
Cost comparison through industry benchmarking
Availability of adequate funds for procurement

questions.explanation: Capacity Management success would depend to a great extent upon the availability of precise and timely business forecast, as indicated in the answer in Option B. The answers in other options are incorrect.

questions.question: With reference to Capex & Opex, how can valuation of any business be improved ?

options.text: Increasing Capex & proportionately reducing Opex
Reduction in Opex irrespective of impact on day-to-day operations
With Capex constant, reduction in Opex without hurting day-to-day operations
Increasing both Capex & Opex with the objective of increased profits

questions.explanation: In general, industry prefers to restrict Capex & also optimize Opex to get best results for stakeholders. Capex is considered undesirable owing to restrictions on dividend cost being allowed as a business cost for tax purposes unlike Opex. However reduction in Opex can hurt operations too, leading to reduced profits. Hence, the ideal situation would be, while Capex is kept constant, Opex is reduced without hurting day-to-operations, as indicated in Option C above. The answers in other 0ptions are incorrect.

questions.question: What is Information ?

options.text: It is a collection of data which need not necessarily have meaning for its user
It is restricted to data in the form of numbers
It is data which is not necessarily specific & organized
It is all data processed in a meaningful context

questions.explanation: Information is data processed in a meaningful context. It is specific & organized and has value to the user. It includes all forms of information like numbers, text, images, sound, codes, etc. Hence, the answer at Option D is correct & the other options incorrect.

questions.question: State TRUE or FALSE. When the Information System Auditor delegates work to others, he will continue to be responsible for forming and expressing his opinion on auditee environment as per the scope and objectives of the audit.

options.text: TRUE
FALSE

questions.explanation: The responsibility for forming and expressing opinion on auditee environment rests with the IS Auditor even in respect of work he delegates to others. Hence, answer at Option A above is correct.

questions.question: Are Audit professionals considered to be the most appropriate professionals to audit Information Systems (rather than IT professionals) ?

options.text: No; since they do not have adequate expertise in Information Technology
Yes; since it involves the evaluation of internal controls in computerized business processes
No; since Information systems have built-in safeguards and an audit would be superfluous
Yes; but only to the extent of regulatory matters about which they are proficient

questions.explanation: Audit professionals are, indeed, considered to be the most appropriate professionals to audit Information systems since knowledge of business processes is extremely critical for such audit, more than that of technical knowledge of Information technology. What is required is an audit professional who has supplemented his audit/financial/regulatory background with knowledge of the basics of Information technology. Hence, answer at Option B above is correct. IS can build safeguards to meet all contingencies. The other answers are, therefore, incorrect.

questions.question: Risk in Information Technology ____________

options.text: Can be depicted as hierarchically dependent upon other risk categories
Does not impact on long term strategy
Can also be defined as Threat exploiting Vulnerabilities
Is not considered operational in financial industry as per Basel II framework

questions.explanation: Since Information systems impinge on each and every part of an organization s business today, any risks in IT would automatically extend to all aspects of the business. It is, in fact, considered even an operational risk in the financial industry as per Basel II framework. However, since it is relevant to different aspects of an organization, it is not to be depicted as hierarchically dependent upon other risk categories. Hence, answers in Options A, B and D are incorrect. However, the definition given in Option C is correct it is, in a way, threat exploiting vulnerabilities. Hence, answer at Option C above is correct.

questions.question: What is the Risk Universe ?

options.text: Is restricted to selected components of the business
Is restricted to the enterprise & excludes suppliers, service providers, clients
It needs to be defined & frozen for a reasonable period of time of about 5 years
It defines the overall environment & provides a structure for managing the IT risk

questions.explanation: The Risk Universe extends to the overall environment, covering all stake holders including suppliers, service providers & clients. It aims at providing a structure for managing IT risk. It crosses functional silos and is intended to cover end-to-end business perspective. It needs to be dynamic & updated regularly to be aligned with changes in the environment. Hence, answer at Option D alone is correct.

questions.question: During 2009, the Satyam Computers scandal broke out. The Company s Chairman admitted to falsification of accounts to the tune of U.S. $ 1.47 billion. The auditors for this company were mainly exposed to what type of risk ?

options.text: Audit Risk
Financial Risk
Procedural Risk
IT Risk

questions.explanation: Audit risk refers to the risk that an auditor may issue unqualified report due to the auditor s failure to detect material misstatement either due to error or fraud. The cited example clearly refers to such a situation and, hence, answer at Option A above is the correct answer.

questions.question: Audit risk is _______________

options.text: A product of control risk & detection risk
A product of inherent risk, control risk & detection risk
Sum of inherent risk, control risk & detection risk
A product of inherent risk and detection risk

questions.explanation: Audit risk refers to the risk that an auditor may issue unqualified report due to the auditor s failure to detect material misstatement either due to error or fraud. It is a product of inherent risk, control risk & detection risk. Hence, answer at Option B alone is correct.

questions.question: In the case of IS Audit, materiality is _____________

options.text: Based upon value and volume of transactions
Based on impact of non compliance
Consequence of risk in terms of potential loss
A product of inherent risk and detection risk

questions.explanation: Materiality in IS Audit is a consequence of risk in terms of potential loss. Hence, answer at Option C is correct while the other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: In the case of Financial audit, materiality is ______________

options.text: Based upon value and volume of transactions
Based on impact of non compliance
Consequence of risk in terms of potential loss
A product of inherent risk and detection risk

questions.explanation: Materiality in Financial Audit is based upon value and volume of transactions and the relevant error or discrepancy or control weakness detected. Hence, answer at Option A is correct while the other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: In the case of Regulatory audit, materiality is _________________

options.text: Based upon value and volume of transactions
Consequence of risk in terms of potential loss
Based on impact of non- compliance
A product of inherent risk and detection risk

questions.explanation: Materiality in Regulatory Audit is based upon the impact of non-compliance with regulations. Hence, answer at Option C is correct while the other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: Internal Controls _______________

options.text: Are restricted to tools for prevention of risks alone
Focus exclusively on financial rather than non-financial risks
Are driven exclusively by automated computerised systems
Facilitate achievement of business objectives & management of risks

questions.explanation: Internal controls are designed to assure the management that the organization s business objectives will be achieved and risk events prevented or detected and corrected. They target prevention as well as detection & correction and are aimed at both financial as well as non-financial risks. They can be driven either by automated computerised systems or even manual systems. Hence, answer at Option D alone is correct.

questions.question: Internal Controls ________________

options.text: Target risk management rather than achievement of business objectives
Comprise Preventive, Detective & Corrective controls
Are driven exclusively by automated computerised systems
Focus exclusively on financial rather than non-financial risks

questions.explanation: Internal controls are designed to assure the management that the organization s business objectives will be achieved and risk events prevented or detected and corrected. They target prevention as well as detection & correction and are aimed at both financial as well as non-financial risks. They can be driven either by automated computerised systems or even manual systems. Hence, answer at Option B alone is correct.

questions.question: Internal Controls _______________

options.text: Are the sum total of IT General controls and IT Application Controls
Focus exclusively on prevention of errors or irregularities
Are driven exclusively by automated computerised systems
Focus exclusively on financial rather than non-financial risks

questions.explanation: Internal controls are designed to assure the management that the organization s business objectives will be achieved and risk events prevented or detected and corrected. They target prevention as well as detection & correction and are aimed at both financial as well as non-financial risks. They can be driven either by automated computerised systems or even manual systems. They include General controls which encompass all administrative areas and Application controls which are related to specific application software. Hence, answer at Option A alone is correct.

questions.question: The authority, scope and responsibility of the Information System Audit function is ________________

options.text: Defined by the I.T. Head of the organization, as the expert in the matter
Defined by the various functional divisions, depending upon criticality
Defined by the audit charter approved by the senior management/Board
Generated by the Audit division of the organization

questions.explanation: The authority, scope and responsibility of the Information system audit is invariably defined by the audit charter which is approved by the senior management and, most often, by the Board of Directors. It is not left to the Audit division, the IT Head or the functional heads to decide on this. Hence, answer at Option C alone is correct..

questions.question: Audit objectives, in general _____________

options.text: Are not concerned with substantiation of internal controls
Refer to the specific goals that must be met by audit
Are not concerned with how internal controls function
Are derived & stated at the end of the audit process

questions.explanation: Audit objectives refer to the specific goals that must be met by audit. This is in contrast to a control objective which refers to how an internal control functions. They often focus on substantiating the existence of internal controls & the appropriateness of functioning. They are invariably set down at the beginning of the audit process. Hence answer at Option B alone is correct.

questions.question: The major purpose of Information Systems Audit is whether _____________

options.text: Internal control system design is robust & operated effectively
Financials are properly reflected in the books of the organization
All the hardware in the organization have appropriate warranties
All the software in the organization have valid licences

questions.explanation: A major purpose of Information Systems audit is whether the internal control system design is robust and is operated effectively. It is not directly related to ensuring financial correctness or to validate warranties/licences for hardware/software. Hence, answer at Option A alone is correct.

questions.question: A Request for Proposal (RFP) _______________

options.text: Is sent by prospective supplier to buyer, seeking information
Will help identify the lowest-priced bidder as the successful bidder
Is used for acquiring services &, sometimes, goods
Is used exclusively for buying goods and not services

questions.explanation: A RFP is used primarily for acquiring services and, on occasion, goods. It comprises a complete description of the buyer s requirements of the service/product. The successful bidder in this process need not necessarily be the lowest-priced; non-financial aspects like credibility, technical superiority, etc. will also be taken into account to arrive at the optimal supplier. Hence, answer at Option C alone is correct.

questions.question: You are advising your client on the selection & appointment of an IT service provider. You suggest that the client should go through a Request for Proposal (RFP) process for best results. Your client is happy with your suggestion but requests that not all aspects of the selection process be publicised up-front. For, the client had faced situations in the past wherein, openness in such matters had lead to issues of disputes with suppliers who were rejected in the selection process. The client s argument is that, in any case, the selection will be on a fair and equitable basis & the idea is just to avoid giving too much information to the bidders and create the potential for nuisance attacks by mischievous, unsuccessful bidders. As a Chartered Accountant, would your suggestion be to clearly spell out the selection criteria or leave it ambiguous ?

options.text: Clearly spell out the selection criteria
Leave the selection criteria ambiguous

questions.explanation: It would be best to clearly spell out all the selection criteria. For, it would give confidence to the potential bidders about the credibility of the buyer and also avoid build up of un-necessary cushions to take care of any unknown contingencies. Also, ambiguities cut both ways & may provide loopholes for unscrupulous bidders to wriggle out of commitments or raise disputes. Contractually & legally speaking, too, such a RFP will strengthen the organization s hands in the event of any default or failure on the part of the chosen supplier. Hence, answer at Option A alone is correct.

questions.question: What are the elements common to both the Audit Charter and Audit Engagement Letter ?

options.text: Responsibility, Authority & Professional Fees payable
Responsibility, Authority & Travel expenses budget for auditors
Responsibility, Authority & Accountability

questions.explanation: The elements common to both the Audit Charter & Audit Engagement Letter are Responsibility, Authority & Accountability. Aspects like the Professional fees payable, travel expenses budget for auditors, etc. are generally dealt with in the Engagement Letter and not in the Charter. Hence, answer at Option C alone is correct.

questions.question: Based upon scope, objectives, etc. drawn up in consultation with the senior management of an organization, an experienced audit team which has sound knowledge of I.T. has completed & filed its preliminary audit report of the I.T. department of the organization. On receiving the draft report, the officials in the I.T. department react negatively to the report. They argue that the bulk of the conclusions drawn in the report, the information reported, etc. are erroneous. They question the validity of the findings. In your view, which one of the following could be the likely major cause for this situation ?

options.text: Lack of adequate technical IT knowledge of the auditing team
Poor quality of audit by the team
Malafide intentions of the auditee team
In-effective communication with Auditee & buy-in

questions.explanation: It is clear that the auditing team is a competent one with sound knowledge of I.T. It is unlikely that the auditee team deliberately sought to scuttle the auditing team s report. For, given the fact that they have the top management s approval, the I.T. department cannot hope to gain anything by throwing mud on the auditing team. If the auditee still questions the validity of the team s report, the single major cause which can be inferred from the question stem is that the communication to the auditee has not been carried out in an effective manner & adequate steps have not been taken to secure auditee buy-in for the process . Hence, answer at Option D appears to be more appropriate.

questions.question: You have just taken on the Audit of a large, established multinational company with operations spread geographically across continents. You need to draw up detailed scope of the proposed audit of the organization in consultation with its top management. Your approach would be to focus upon _____________

options.text: Areas identified to be high risk &/or high significance to the organization
Sample audit of each and every geographical unit of the organization
Sample audit of each and every function in the organization
Areas related to I.T. software and hardware alone

questions.explanation: Given the fact that any audit team would have limitations in terms of auditing resources as well as budget, it would have to get maximum mileage for the auditee with the limited resources at its disposal. Hence, rather than spreading itself too thin by trying to audit as many areas as possible, the ideal strategy would be to arrive at a consensus regarding a few areas of high risk as also high significance for the organization. Auditing these areas alone initially would help maximise the value of the auditing exercise. Hence, answer at Option A is the most appropriate one.

questions.question: You have just taken on the Audit of a large, established company with diverse businesses involving manufacturing as well as trading. You are now at the planning stage & need to draw up your draft audit plan for clearance by the top management. What is the most important planning activity involved at this stage of the exercise ?

options.text: Historical financial for the organization
Cost of carrying out the audit
Thorough understanding of the nature of each of the businesses & nuances
Number of people required for carrying out the auditing exercise

questions.explanation: Considering the diverse nature of the organization s businesses as also its existence both in trading as well as manufacturing, the fundamental drivers of these areas of business are likely to be totally different. The most important part of the planning exercise would hence be the thorough understanding of each of the organization s businesses & its nuances. This alone will help the auditor to appreciate the areas of significance & high risk so that focus can be shifted to these areas for maximum results. Hence, answer at Option C above is the most appropriate.

questions.question: Which are the three major categories of IS Controls ?

options.text: Fiduciary, Quality & Security
Financial, Quality & Security
Audit, Quality & Security
Economic, Financial & Quality

questions.explanation: The major categories of IS Controls are Fiduciary, Quality & Security. Hence, answer at Option A above is the correct one.

questions.question: The basic principles of Fiduciary Controls in Information Systems are ____________

options.text: Efficiency & Effectiveness of process, service or activity
Reliability of information & Compliance with laws, regulations, etc.
Confidentiality & Integrity of information
Confidentiality, Integrity & Availability of information

questions.explanation: The basic principle of Fiduciary Controls in IS are reliability of information & compliance with laws, regulations, etc.. Hence, the correct answer is as per Option B. The other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: The basic principles of Quality Controls in Information Systems are ____________

options.text: Reliability of information & Compliance with laws, regulations, etc.
Confidentiality & Integrity of information
Efficiency & Effectiveness of process, service or activity
Confidentiality, Integrity & Availability of information

questions.explanation: The basic principle of Quality Controls in IS are efficiency & effectiveness of processes, services or activities. Hence, the correct answer is as per Option C. The other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: The basic principles of Security Controls in Information Systems are ____________

options.text: Confidentiality, Integrity & Availability of information
Reliability of information & Compliance with laws, regulations, etc.
Efficiency & Effectiveness of process, service or activity
Confidentiality & Integrity of information

questions.explanation: The basic principle of Security Controls in IS are Confidentiality, Integrity & Availability of information. Hence, the correct answer is as per Option A. The other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the four Areas which have to be understood by Information System Auditors prior to commencement of audit ?

options.text: Thorough understanding of the business of the entity
Efficiency & Effectiveness of process, service or activity
Sales turnover & employee strength of the entity
Status of entity whether government or private

questions.explanation: One of the Areas which have to be understood by Information System Auditors is thorough understanding of the business of the entity. Hence, the correct answer is as per Option A. The other answers are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the four Areas which have to be understood by Information System Auditors prior to commencement of audit ?

options.text: Status of entity whether government or private
Efficiency & Effectiveness of process, service or activity
Organization structure, roles, responsibilities, policy framework, etc.

Information Technology Act, 2000, Section 43 A

questions.question: A famous cinema actor has learnt that his password and personal information on a social networking website have been compromised owing to suspected breach of the security of the relevant networking website. questions.question: A small scale industry has developed an effective, organic mosquito repellent which shows great promise. options.text: Sarbanes Oxley Act, 2002, Sections 401 to 403
Information Technology Act 2000, Sections 43A
Right to Information Security Act, 2006, Section 7A

questions.question: In addition to giving opinion on the fair presentation of the organization s accounts, an independent auditor of an organization is expected to opine on the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as per a particular Act. Information Technology Act 2000, Section 7A

questions.question: What does Auditing Standard 5 of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) relate to ?

questions.question: Corporate governance, including internal controls, enterprise risk management, etc. are covered under the provisions of ______________

Section 126A of the Sarbanes Oxley Act 2002
Section 14A of the Gramm Leach Bliley Act or the Financial Services Modernisation Act 1999

questions.question: ISO/IEC 27000 is basically a/an ______________

Auditing related standard
Standard for quality in auditing
Generic standard for quality in accounting

IS / IEC 27001
IS /IEC 24007

questions.question: Information Technology Assurance Framework (ITAF) ___________

Standards are divided into two categories
Standards are divided into four categories
Is not recognized by ISACA

General, industry specific and non-financial standards
General, performance and reporting standards
Macro, micro and non-financial standards

Are the guiding principles under which IS assurance profession operates

Are yet to be validated & approved by ISACA

Is a framework for governance & management of enterprise IT
Can be useful only for large organizations with ERP systems

questions.question: In order to protect its critical data from virus attacks an organisation decides to limit internet access to its employees. What type of risk response has the organisation exercised?

Avoid
Accept
Transfer

B Avoid is not correct as the organisation is not avoiding the use of technology to avoid risks C Accept is not correct as the organisation has not chosen to accept the risk D transfer is not correct as the organisation is not passing on the risk to another entity

questions.question: A production company decides to insure against production loss due to natural calamities. What type of response is this classified as?

options.text: Mitigate
Accept
Transfer
Avoid

questions.explanation: C Transfer is correct as the organisation passes on the risk to the insurance company. A: Mitigate is not correct as the organisation is not implementing any controls within B: Accept is not correct as organisation has not accepted the risk D Avoid is not correct as the organisation has not decided to avoid technology to minimise risk

questions.question: Implementation of Information system control in an organisation ensures that:

options.text: Risk is transferred to another entity
Desired Outcome from business process is not affected
Losses are avoided
Incidents due to risk materialisation are avoided

questions.explanation: B is correct Information Control includes implementation of policies, procedures and practices which ensure that the desired outcome from business is not affected A is not correct this is a type of risk response C & D are not correct They are not a direct result of implementation of controls

questions.question: Which of the following leads to destruction of information Assets such as hardware, software and critical data?

options.text: Data error during data entry
Non maintenance of privacy with respect to sensitive data
Unauthorised access to computer systems
Using systems that do not meet user requirements

questions.explanation: C is correct - Unauthorised access to computer systems, computer viruses, unauthorised physical access to computer facilities and unauthorised copies of sensitive data can lead to destruction of assets A is not correct data error causes damage to the business process only B is not correct non maintenance of privacy does not cause damage to Information Assets, it infringes on the privacy of the customer D is not correct this is a system efficiency objective

questions.question: Maintenance of privacy in relation to data collected by an organisation is very important because:

options.text: Errors committed during entry would cause great damage

questions.question: The role of an internal auditor in Information Systems auditing includes:

questions.question: What does an external Information Systems auditor focus on?

options.text: Attesting objectives that focus on asset safeguarding and data integrity

Attesting system efficiency

This is the responsibility of the organisatio006E

questions.question: By auditing the characteristics of the system to meet substantial user requirements, which control objective does an IS Auditor attest?

options.text: Data integrity objectives
System Effectiveness Objectives
Asset safeguarding objectives
System efficiency objectives

questions.explanation: B is correct - Effectiveness of a system is evaluated by auditing the characteristics and objective of the system to meet substantial user requirements. A is incorrect the auditor checks the extent of access to information and the value of data to business C is incorrect the auditor assesses the internal controls to protect software and hardware D is incorrect the auditor assesses the optimal usage of system resources

questions.question: A statement of purpose achieved by implementing control procedures in a particular IT process is defined as:

options.text: IS Control framework
Internal Controls
Control Objective
Preventive Controls

questions.explanation: C is correct - Control objective is defined as A statement of the desired result or purpose to be achieved by implementing control procedures in a particular IT process or activity B is incorrect it is the basic outline of the policies of the organisation towards IS control A & D are incorrect these are the steps taken by the organisation to protect information and system assets

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of technical implementation of Internal Control?

options.text: Outlining policies that safeguard information assets
Installing a security guard in the premises to restrict entry of unauthorised persons
Locking the room containing sensitive documents
Investing in tools and software to restrict unauthorised access to information

questions.explanation: D is correct - this is an example of technical implementation B is incorrect this is an example of administrative implementation A & C are incorrect these are examples of physical implications

questions.question: What are preventive controls?

options.text: those mechanisms which refer unlawful activities to the appropriate person/group
those controls which attempt to predict potential problems before they occur
those mechanisms which modify the processing system to minimise error occurrences
those controls which corrects the error arising from a problem

questions.explanation: B is correct - Preventive controls attempts to predict problems before they occur and make necessary adjustments. They are designed to protect the organisation from unauthorised activities A is incorrect this is a characteristic of detective control C & D are incorrect these are characteristics of corrective control

questions.question: What are detective controls?

options.text: Provision for control of probable threats from materializing
Those controls that are designed to detect errors and omissions of malicious acts
Those controls which assess probable threats
Those controls which minimise the impact of threat

questions.explanation: B is correct - These controls are designed to detect errors, omissions of malicious acts that occur and reporting the occurrence. A & C are incorrect this is a characteristic of preventive control D is incorrect this is a characteristic of corrective control

questions.question: What are corrective controls?

options.text: Those controls that correct an error once it has been detected
Those mechanisms which provide a clear understanding of the vulnerabilities of an asset
Surprise checks by an administrator
Those mechanisms by which the management gets regular reports of spend to date against a profiled spend

questions.explanation: A is correct - These controls are designed to reduce the impact or correct an error once it has been detected. B is incorrect this is a characteristic of preventive control C is incorrect this is a characteristic of detective control D is incorrect this is an example of detective control

questions.question: An organisation decides to control the access to a software application by segregating entry level and updation level duties. What type of internal control does this amount to?

options.text: Preventive Control
Detective Control
Corrective Control
physical implementation of a control

questions.explanation: A is correct - Examples of preventive controls include employing qualified personnel, segregation of duties, access control, documentation etc. B and C are incorrect detective and corrective controls are not designed to predict potential problems D is incorrect physical implementation of a control includes only physical aspects like security guards and locked rooms

questions.question: Under which type of control mechanism does taking a back up of everyday activity classify as?

options.text: Detective Control
Preventive control
Corrective control
Administrative Implementation of Control

questions.explanation: C is correct Examples of Corrective Controls are - contingency planning, backup and restoration procedure, rerun procedure, procedure for treating error, etc. A & B are incorrect Detective and Preventive controls are not designed to reduce the impact or correct an error once it has been detected. D is incorrect Administrative implications of controls are items such as policies and processes

questions.question: As an IS auditor, how would you rate a computerised detective control which is moderately efficient and with corresponding corrective action?

options.text: High
Low
Moderate
Blank

questions.explanation: A is correct - Computerised control which is most effective, generally controls that are computerized and applied before processing can take place; moderately efficient, with corresponding corrective action are rated as High B, C and D are incorrect Moderate- Controls implemented over a cause of exposure/error type and is moderately effective. Low-Controls implemented over a cause of exposure/error type but have low effectiveness. Blank- Controls not implemented or does not exist to that cause or exposure or error type.

questions.question: As an IS auditor, how would you rate a least effective and inefficient manual detective control without corrective action?

options.text: High
Low
Blank
Moderate

questions.explanation: C is correct - Manual control which is least effective, generally manual controls applied at front-end of processing; moderately efficient are rated as Blank A, B & D are incorrect High- Controls implemented over a cause of exposure/error type and should be highly effective. questions.question: Which of the following describes the role of a risk owner?

options.text: Ensuring that all control objectives that focus on asset safeguarding and data integrity are attested
Ensuring that the risk response is effective enough and is translated into actions that will prevent and/or detect the risk.
Ensuring that all system effectiveness and system efficiency objectives are attested

questions.explanation: B is correct - Generally owner is a person or position within the organization that has close interest about the processes affected due to risk. The person responsible needs to ensure that the risk response is translated into actual day-to-day actions that will prevent and/or detect the risk. A, C and D are incorrect These are the roles of IS auditors

questions.question: The process of Information Security does not end with implementation of risk responses. The next step is to:

options.text: Facilitate to conduct risk assessment workshops
Ensure that business risks are being managed appropriately
Plan the audit cycle according to the perceived risk
Ensure that the identified risk stays within an acceptable threshold

questions.explanation: D is correct - After implementation of the risk responses and management techniques, the managers need to monitor the actual activities to ensure that the identified risk stays within an acceptable threshold. A, B and C are incorrect these are the roles that an auditor has to perform in view of control assessment

questions.question: What process must an organisation follow to ensure that the identified risk stays within the acceptable limits?

options.text: Evaluate the efficiency of the objectives of controls
Designing an effective internal control framework
Periodic review of the risk assessment exercise and proactive review of possible risks
Optimise the use of various information resources

questions.explanation: C is correct - To ensure that risks are reviewed and updated organizations must have a process that will ensure the review of risks. Periodic review: the risk assessment exercise may be conducted after predefined period say annual. Change management processes proactively review the possible risks and ensure they are part of organization s risk register. A B and D are incorrect these are steps to be taken towards identifying, assessing risks and implementing internal controls

questions.question: How does an IS auditor prioritise the controls that needs to be tested?

options.text: By reviewing the control catalogue (which is a collective record of all controls implemented)
By reviewing control procedure documents
By facilitating risk assessment workshops
Planning the audit cycle according to the risks perceived

questions.explanation: A is correct - The first step in control s assessment is to review the control catalogue (which is a collective record of all controls implemented) and ensure that associated risk is mitigated either by reducing likelihood or reducing impact or both. B is incorrect This should be done after reviewing the control procedure documents C and D are incorrect These are the roles of an auditor with respect to Information risk management

questions.question: In case of control self assessment, who does the actual testing of controls?

options.text: The owner of the identified risk for which the control has been implemented
Internal auditor, during the audit cycle as planned
Staff whose day-to-day role is within the area of the organisation
External auditor, while reviewing the management of risks

questions.question: Of the below mentioned roles, which one should an auditor refrain from performing?

options.text: Giving assurance that the risks are being evaluated correctly
Implementing risk response on management s behalf.
Evaluating the risk management process
Reviewing the management of risks

questions.explanation: B is correct - This is the job of the management, an auditor only needs to review the risk response A, C and D are incorrect these are the roles of an IS auditor

questions.question: Of the below mentioned roles, which one of the following should be performed by an IS auditor?

options.text: Set the risk appetite
Impose risk management process
Evaluate Risk Management process
Take decision on risk responses

questions.explanation: C is correct - Evaluating the risk management process is the role of an IS auditor A, B and D are incorrect these are the roles of the management and the risk owner.

questions.question: A data centre housing about 200 employees is involved in handling businesses processes of multinational companies. For security reasons, it decides to shift its network server and mail server to a secluded room with restricted entry. What kind of internal control is this?

options.text: Manual Preventive Control
Manual Detective Control
Computerised Preventive Control
Computerised Corrective Control

B, C and D are incorrect The action does not categorise under any of these categories for the reasons mentioned above.

questions.question: Company depends on an MIS given to it by an outsourced vendor to identify payment defaulters and fine them. options.text: Blank
Low
Moderate
High

questions.question: The HR department of a company pays its employees medical claims subject to a maximum limit per employee per year. questions.question: A data centre handling outsourced operations decides to set up a parallel facility for its critical activities at some place other than its present place of operations. options.text: Business Continuity Management Policy
Acceptable use of Information Assets policy
Physical Access and Security Policy
Asset Management Policy

questions.explanation: A is correct - This policy defines the requirements to ensure continuity of business critical operations. It is designed to minimize the impact of an unforeseen event (or disaster) and to facilitate return of business to normal levels. B is incorrect - An acceptable use policy (AUP), also known as an Acceptable Usage policy or Fair Use policy, is a set of rules applied by the owner or manager of a network, website or large computer system that restrict the ways in which the network, website or system may be used. C is incorrect - Physical security describes security measures that are designed to restrict unauthorized access to facilities, equipment and resources, and to protect personnel and property from damage or harm (such as espionage, theft, or terrorist attacks). D is incorrect This policy defines the requirements for Information Asset s protection. It includes assets like servers, desktops, handhelds, software, network devices etc. Besides, it covers all assets used by an organization- owned or leased.

questions.question: What are the three objectives of Information Security Management (CIA Triad)?

Confidentiality, Information Security and Availability
Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability
Confidentiality, Integrity and Asset Management

A, B and D are incorrect Though important for Information Security, these are not the components.

questions.question: What does Integrity mean with respect to Information Security Management?

options.text: No data/information or programs shall be allowed to be modified by anyone without proper authority.
No data or information is made available to any person within or outside the organization, other than the persons who are authorized to use that data.
All Information Systems including hardware, communication networks, software applications and the data they hold, is available to authorized users to carry out business activities.
Executive management endorsement of intrinsic security requirements to ensure that security expectations are met at all levels of the enterprise

questions.explanation: A is correct This is the correct definition as per paragraph 2.1 of the chapter B and C are incorrect these are definitions of Confidentiality and Availability D is incorrect this clause pertains to Senior Management Commitment and support

questions.question: What provides the basis for ensuring that information security expectations are met at all levels of an enterprise?

options.text: Adopting an internationally recognized reference framework to establish an Information Security framework
Successful establishment and endorsement of intrinsic security measures by the senior management
Prioritising expenditures to mitigate risks and avoid spending more resources in assessing risks
Ensuring that the framework followed to implement, maintain, monitor and improve Information Security is consistent with the organisational culture.

questions.explanation: B is correct - Commitment and support from senior management are important for successful establishment and continuance of an information security management program. A C and D are incorrect These are some of the critical success factors to Information Security Management.

questions.question: How does an enterprise ensure that the information present in any of its business processes is protected and secure?

options.text: By ensuring that the framework followed to implement, maintain, monitor and improve Information Security is consistent with the organisational culture.
By adopting an internationally recognized reference framework to establish an Information Security framework
By spending resources widely and transparently
By establishing and enforcing an Information Security Program

questions.explanation: D is correct - Information Security program focuses on protecting information present in business processes. Establish a program to improve Information Security management enterprise-wide and enforce it. A B, and C are incorrect These are other critical success factors to Information Security Management.

questions.question: How does an enterprise demonstrate to staff, customers and trading partners that their data is safe?

options.text: By establishing and enforcing an Information Security Program
By ensuring that the framework followed to implement, maintain, monitor and improve Information Security is consistent with the organisational culture.
Adopting an information security standard
By spending resources widely and transparently

questions.explanation: C is correct - Adopting an information security standard seems to demonstrate to staff, customers and trading partners that their data is safe, and that there is an independent verification of this fact. A B and D are incorrect These are other critical success factors to Information Security Management.

questions.question: The IS policy of an enterprise that talks about protecting non-public personal information from unauthorised use, corruption, disclosure and distribution is:

options.text: Acceptable usage policy or Fair Use policy
Data classification and Privacy Policy
Physical Access and Security policy
Asset Management Policy

questions.explanation: B is correct - the policy of the Organization to protect against the unauthorized access, use, corruption, disclosure, and distribution of non-public personal information in its possession, and to comply with all applicable laws and regulations regarding such information is termed as the Data Classification and privacy policy A is incorrect is a set of rules applied by the owner or manager of a network, website or large computer system C is incorrect Physical security describes security measures that are designed to restrict unauthorized access to facilities, equipment and resources D is incorrect - This policy defines the requirements for Information Asset s protection

questions.question: The policy which restricts the ways in which the network, website or system may be used by a user of an enterprise is termed as:

options.text: Acceptable usage policy or Fair Use policy
Physical Access and Security policy
Asset Management Policy
Business Continuity Management Policy

questions.explanation: A is correct - An acceptable use policy (AUP), also known as an Acceptable Usage policy or Fair Use policy, is a set of rules applied by the owner or manager of a network, website or large computer system that restrict the ways in which the network, website or system may be used. B is incorrect Physical security describes security measures that are designed to restrict unauthorized access to facilities, equipment and resources C is incorrect - This policy defines the requirements for Information Asset s protection D is incorrect - This policy defines the requirements to ensure continuity of business critical operations.

questions.question: The IS policy which talks about protecting personnel and physical property from damage or harm is termed as:

options.text: Asset Management policy
Business Continuity Management policy
Physical access and security policy
Password policy

questions.explanation: C is correct - Physical security describes security measures that are designed to restrict unauthorized access to facilities, equipment and resources, and to protect personnel and property from damage or harm (such as espionage, theft, or terrorist attacks). A is incorrect - This policy defines the requirements for Information Asset s protection B is incorrect - This policy defines the requirements to ensure continuity of business critical operations. D is incorrect - This policy defines high-level configuration of password to be used within organization to access the information assets.

questions.question: What is the IS policy that defines the requirements for Information Assets protection?

options.text: Business Continuity Management Policy
Asset Management Policy
Network Security Policy
Password policy

questions.explanation: B is correct - This policy defines the requirements for Information Asset s protection. It includes assets like servers, desktops, handhelds, software, network devices etc. Besides, it covers all assets used by an organization- owned or leased. A is incorrect - This policy defines the requirements to ensure continuity of business critical operations. C is incorrect - A network security policy defines the overall rules for organisation s network access D is incorrect - This policy defines high-level configuration of password to be used within organization to access the information assets.

questions.question: The characteristics of a strong password that protects information assets should be:

options.text: Maximum 8 characters, case specific
Minimum 8 characters, only alpha numeric
Minimum 8 characters, only alphabets and easy to remember
Minimum 8 characters, case specific and containing special characters

questions.explanation: D is correct - The password policy defines high-level configuration of password to be used within organization to access the information assets. For example: Password length must be more than 8 characters Password must be complex containing upper case, lower case, numeric and special characters Password must be changed regularly Password should not be used again for minimum period Password should not be changed in consecutive sequence A B and C are incorrect These are not the characteristics of a strong password

questions.question: What should be done to ensure that security policies are in tune with the management s intent?

options.text: Change passwords regularly
Restrict unauthorised access to facilities
Review the security policies periodically
Hold non public personal information in strict confidence

questions.explanation: C is correct - Information security policies need to be maintained and updated regularly. This might need to revisit the security requirements and hence policies. Hence, it is necessary to review the security policies periodically to ensure that they are in line with the management s intent. A, B and D are incorrect These are the parts of an information security policy

questions.question: Policies are generic and sometimes cannot be enforced in specific situations. Can there be a relaxation of adherence to policy in such cases?

options.text: Yes. But, it is necessary to ensure that there are suitable compensating controls
Yes. Policies can be relaxed in case of such situations unconditionally
No. Under no circumstances can an Information Security policy be relaxed
Yes. Adherence to the policy can be relaxed for an indefinite period for the specific activity only.

questions.explanation: A is correct - In such situations it is necessary to ensure there are suitable compensating controls so that the risks mitigated by enforcement of policy are within acceptable limits. B, C and D are incorrect Policies can be relaxed for a specific period provided the exceptions are appropriately approved and these exceptions must be reviewed periodically.

questions.question: Standards, Guidelines and Procedures are the three elements of policy implementation. In what order should they be followed for proper implementation?

options.text: Guidelines, Procedures and Standards
Procedures, Standards and Guidelines
Standards, Guidelines and Procedures
Guidelines, Standards and Procedures

questions.explanation: C is correct - The next level down from policies is three elements of policy implementation as given here: Standards: Specify the uniform way for the use of specific technologies in an organization. Guidelines: Guidelines are similar to standards; they refer to the methodologies of securing systems, but they are only recommended actions and are not compulsory. Procedures: Procedure contains the detailed steps that are followed to perform a specific task. Procedures are the detailed actions that must be followed. A, B and D are incorrect These do not specify the correct levels of implementation. Unless Standards are set, guidelines cannot be recommended. Unless guidelines are recommended, procedures cannot be outlined for implementing policies.

questions.question: With respect to Information Security, what does Segregation of Duties mean?

options.text: No individual, of whatever seniority in the organization, should have the ability to carry out every step of a sensitive business transaction.
The responsibility of powerful and access to the system should not be carried out by one person alone.
No person should be kept in one particular post for too long
Organisations should avoid situations where an individual becomes indispensable to the business

questions.explanation: A is correct - No individual, of whatever seniority in the organization, should have the ability to carry out every step of a sensitive business transaction. Access to too many functions enables staff to carry out a fraudulent transaction and hide their tracks. B is incorrect This pertains to the Four Eyes or Two Person principle C is incorrect This pertains to rotation of duties D is incorrect This pertains to Man policies

questions.question: In a bank, the chest in which cash is kept has to be opened with two Answer:s, one which is in the control of the manager and the other which is in the control of the accountant/sub manager. Under what security rule does this aspect classify?

options.text: Segregation of Duties
The Four Eyes or Two Person principle
Rotation of Duties
Man policies

questions.explanation: B is correct - To reduce the opportunities for any person to breach security, those responsibilities and duties which would afford particularly powerful access to the system, or which act at control points, should not be carried out by one person alone. A, C and D are incorrect These are other security rules designed for implementation of IS policies

questions.question: An organisation which is IS compliant requires its employees to take two weeks consecutive mandatory leave. Under which security rule does this feature classify as?

options.text: Rotation of duties
Man policies
Two person principle
Segregation of duties

questions.explanation: A is correct - No one person should be kept in one particular post for too long, especially if that appointment involves any particular security responsibilities opportunities for dishonesty. A similar rule should insist that staff take at least two consecutive weeks; holiday in any year, as experience has shown that many frauds need continual masking by the perpetrator and may surface when the individual is away. B, C and D are incorrect These are other security rules designed for implementation of IS policies

questions.question: Every corporate asset, building, item of equipment, bank account and item of information should have a clearly defined owner . What are the responsibilities of the owner of such assets?

options.text: Adding and deleting user identifiers from the system
Defining security responsibilities for every person in the organization
Ensuring that the asset is well maintained, accurate and up to date
Establishing and Implementing an effective IS program

questions.explanation: C is correct - The owner should have a defined set of responsibilities. Ensuring that computer rooms are kept clean and tidy Ensuring that equipment is well maintained and kept operational Ensuring that an item of data used by the organization is accurate and up to date. A,B and D are incorrect These are steps to ensure that Information Security is implemented in an organisation.

questions.question: When an owner is not able to manage a particular asset on a day to day basis, the responsibility is passed on to a custodian. Which of the following is an example of a custodian?

options.text: a vendor responsible for an outsourced activity
data center controlling access to production data
a subordinate doing the function of an owner during his absence
an auditor auditing the effectiveness of an asset

questions.explanation: B is correct - The owner should clearly state the requirements, the responsibilities and associated levels of authority of the custodian and final management responsibility will always reside with the owner. Examples of custodian include a data center operations function controlling access to production data, and a computer bureau running an application for a client. A,C and D are incorrect these are not examples of a custodian. They pertain to roles of other players in Information Security Management.

questions.question: The actual security mechanism has its application in certain tasks of security systems. What are these called as?

options.text: Organisational control
Backup data
Control points
Operating System

questions.explanation: C is correct - In all security systems there are tasks which can be called control points. It is at these control points that the actual security mechanism has its application. A is incorrect this is the control that an organisation places to secure its information assets B is incorrect this is a procedure that is adopted for safeguarding critical data D is incorrect Operating system is a software that manages computer hardware and software resources

questions.question: Name the participant which ensures that all stakeholders impacted by security considerations are involved in the Information Security Management process.

options.text: Steering committee
Information Owner
Information Custodian
System Owner

questions.explanation: A is correct - It serves as an effective communications channel and provides an ongoing basis for ensuring the alignment of the security program with business objectives. It can also be instrumental in achieving modification of behavior toward a culture more conducive to good security. B is incorrect - Information Owner (also called Data Owners) is responsible for a company information asset. C is incorrect Information custodian is assigned the task of implementing the prescribed protection defined by the security procedure D is incorrect The system owner is responsible for one or more systems, each of which may process and store data owned by different information owners.

questions.question: Name the participant who ensures that security controls have been implemented in accordance with the information classification.

options.text: information Custodian
Information Owner
System Owner
Process Owner

questions.explanation: B is correct - Information Owner (also called Data Owners) is responsible for a company information asset. The responsibilities are generally assigned to person/position that owns business process. A is incorrect - Information custodian is assigned the task of implementing the prescribed protection defined by the security procedure C is incorrect The system owner is responsible for one or more systems, each of which may process and store data owned by different information owners. D is incorrect This person is responsible for the implementation, management and continuous improvement of a process that has been defined to meet a business requirement.

questions.question: Name the participant who ensures safe keeping of information on behalf of the information owner.

options.text: System Owner
Process Owner
Information Custodian
System Administrator

questions.explanation: C is correct - Information custodian is assigned the task of implementing the prescribed protection defined by the security procedure and top level/Senior management decisions. Among other activities, information custodian also performs following activities: Ensuring safe keeping of information on behalf of information owner Providing access to users that are approved by owners Running regular backups and routinely testing from backup data Performing data restoration activity from the backups when necessary A is incorrect The system owner is responsible for one or more systems, each of which may process and store data owned by different information owners. B is incorrect This person is responsible for the implementation, management and continuous improvement of a process that has been defined to meet a business requirement. D is incorrect - System Administrator is the one with administrative / root level privileges of the Operating systems like Windows, Unix etc.
